newsitem.title: MEXICO: Mexico coffee exporters deny knowledge of imports.
newsitem.headline: Mexico coffee exporters deny knowledge of imports.

text.p: Three major Mexican coffee exporters said Thursday they had no knowledge of industry plans to import arabica beans because of the shortage in the country.
"I have heard nothing about it," said the director of coffee trading at one major house. "It has been legal for some years but I don't think it will be done." he said.
"If any imports are needed this year, they will be improved robustas not arabicas which are allowed by law," another Mexican trader said, declining to be named.
Exporters said imports are allowed into Mexico of certain types of coffee that pass rigid phytosantitary restrictions, but they are subject to import taxes.
"I don't think anyone will import arabicas because of the price and because of the import taxes they have to pay on top of the beans," said a third Mexican exporter.

Reports have swirled through coffee markets that the Mexican government plans to allow roasters to import 150,000 60-kg bags of arabica beans. Exports from Mexico have surged this year, leaving a short supply of beans in the country.
Spokesmen for the government's Mexican Coffee Council and the National Coffee Industry Association, the roasters umbrella group, were not immediately available for comment.
